deliberation: The verse describes bones being taken from graves as an act of desecration. Though it is symbolically shameful, the wording itself is descriptive and literal rather than figurative; no explicit metaphor, simile, personification, idiom, or other trope is present.

I checked the cultic verbs (loved, served, followed, bowed) toward the sun, moon, and host of heaven; they are literal descriptions of idolatry. The notable figurative expression is the comparison of the exposed bones to dung on the face of the ground.

instances.english_text: they shall become dung upon the face of the earth
target: the bones of the kings, priests, prophets, and people (their post-mortem honor)
ground: utter worthlessness, filth, and public exposure
shame/defilement
moral evaluation in covenant judgment
posture: divine denunciation of their idolatrous leaders and people
instances.explanation: The bones are not literally turned into excrement; their dishonored exposure is pictured as if they were dung, conveying extreme shame and worthlessness.

deliberation: The verse contrasts death and life as choices of the remnant. While this could be psychologically literal (hoping for death), it functions rhetorically as a heightened way to describe misery. I treat this preference for death over life as hyperbolic emphasis rather than a concrete report.

instances.english_text: And death shall be preferable to life
target: the lived experience of the surviving remnant
ground: their life will be so bitter that continued existence is intolerable
intensity of suffering
covenant curse experience
instances.explanation: Preferring death to life dramatizes the severity of coming anguish; it is an exaggeration used to underscore the unbearable nature of their fate.

deliberation: The verse uses two everyday physical scenarios (falling and getting up; turning aside and turning back) as analogies for moral and spiritual behavior in the surrounding context. These actions are standard metaphors in Jeremiah for sin and repentance.

instances.hebrew_text: הֲיִפְּלוּ וְלֹא יָקוּמוּ אִם־יָשׁוּב וְלֹא יָשׁוּב
instances.english_text: When people fall, do they not get up again? If they turn aside, do they not turn back?
target: Israel’s moral and spiritual conduct (sin and repentance)
vehicle: falling down and rising; turning aside and returning on a path
ordinary bodily experience of walking and stumbling
ground: just as people naturally recover from a physical fall or wrong turn, so Judah should return from moral deviation
expectability of restoration after failure
norms of response to missteps
instances.explanation: Physical falling and rising, turning aside and returning, are used metaphorically for moral collapse and the expected act of repentance Judah is refusing.

deliberation: The verse describes Jerusalem as a perpetually wayward people and uses movement and grasping language. I see (1) backsliding/waywardness as a path metaphor for spiritual rebellion, and (2) holding fast to deceit as a grasping metaphor for stubborn attachment to falsehood.

instances.hebrew_text: מַדּוּעַ שׁוֹבְבָה הָעָם הַזֶּה יְרוּשָׁלִַם מְשׁוּבָה נִצַּחַת
instances.english_text: Why is this people—Jerusalem—rebellious with a persistent rebellion?
ground: they have turned away from the proper path and remain off-course
ongoing deviation and instability
persistent refusal to walk rightly before God
instances.explanation: Terms from the root שוב portray Judah as a chronically backsliding traveler, picturing spiritual rebellion as straying from the right way.

instances.english_text: They cling to deceit, they refuse to return.
target: the people’s commitment to falsehood and idolatry
vehicle: bodily action of gripping an object
ground: stubborn, tenacious attachment to deception
refusal to let go of sin
willful persistence despite opportunities to repent
instances.explanation: Mental and spiritual attachment to deceit is pictured as physically gripping something, emphasizing their tenacity in error.

deliberation: The key figurative expression is an explicit simile likening their headlong persistence in evil to a war horse rushing into battle. The race imagery in "בִמְרֻצָתָם" is bound up with this same picture, so I treat it as one extended simile.

instances.hebrew_text: כֻּלּוֹ שָׁב בִּמְרֻצָתָם כְּסוּס שׁוֹטֵף בַּמִּלְחָמָה
instances.english_text: They all persist in their wayward course like a steed dashing forward in the fray.
target: the people’s relentless pursuit of their evil ways
vehicle: a war horse charging headlong into battle
ground: unthinking, forceful, and unstoppable forward rush
reckless momentum toward danger
lack of reflection or restraint
posture: sarcastic, critical portrayal of their behavior
instances.explanation: Their persistence in evil is explicitly compared to a war horse that plunges into combat without hesitation, highlighting their reckless and unreflective drive.

deliberation: The birds are said to "know" and "keep" their appointed times; this loosely personifies them and is used to shame Judah by contrast: animals obey natural order, but the people ignore YHWH’s ordinance. The contrast is the rhetorical point.

instances.hebrew_text: גַּם־חֲסִידָה בַשָּׁמַיִם יָדְעָה מוֹעֲדֶיהָ וְתֹר וְסִיס וְעָגֻר שָׁמְרוּ אֶת־עֵת בֹּאָנָה
instances.english_text: Even the stork in the sky knows its seasons, and the turtledove, swift, and crane keep the time of their coming;
target: the instinctive order of migratory birds
vehicle: knowing and keeping appointed times like rational agents
ground: regular, reliable conformity to appointed patterns
obedient response to God-given order
contrast with Judah’s disobedience
posture: ironic rebuke of Judah via comparison to animals
instances.explanation: The birds are described in human terms as knowing and keeping times, in order to highlight that even animals respond properly to divine order, unlike God’s people.

deliberation: The chief figure is "the lying pen of the scribes": the pen is given moral agency and stands for their writings/teaching, making this both personification and metonymy. The rest of the verse is straightforward argument.

instances.english_text: the lying pen of the scribes
target: the deceptive written teaching of the scribes
vehicle: writing instrument as representative of its output
ground: their written interpretations distort truth and mislead
instrumentality in producing falsehood
medium (writing) embodying the character of its authors
posture: sharp prophetic critique of official teaching
instances.explanation: The inanimate pen is personified as a liar and, by metonymy, stands for the scribes’ false writings, underscoring the corruption of their supposed wisdom.

deliberation: The verse speaks of wise men being ashamed, dismayed, and caught because they rejected the word of YHWH. These can all be literal consequences (captivity, disgrace). There is strong rhetoric, but no distinct metaphor, simile, idiom, or other figure that clearly departs from literal description.

Most of the verse is literal judgment language. Two classic Hebrew merisms occur: (1) from small to great, and (2) from prophet to priest, each expressing totality across a spectrum rather than only its endpoints.

instances.hebrew_text: כִּי מִקָּטֹן וְעַד־גָּדוֹל כֻּלּוֹהּ בֹּצֵעַ בָּצַע
instances.english_text: For from the smallest to the greatest, they are all greedy for gain
target: the entire social spectrum of Judah’s people
vehicle: "from small to great" as endpoints of a scale
extremes used to include all in between
ground: corruption pervades every social level without exception
no class is exempt
comprehensiveness of greed
instances.explanation: The phrase "from small to great" is a merism, using both ends of a spectrum to signify that everyone in the social range is implicated.

instances.english_text: prophet and priest alike, they all act falsely
target: the whole range of official religious leadership
vehicle: "from prophet to priest" as flanking representative offices
naming extremes to include all related positions
ground: every kind of religious leader is corrupt
system-wide falseness
no trustworthy officeholder remains
instances.explanation: By pairing prophet and priest as representative offices, the phrase functions as a merism signifying the total corruption of religious leadership.

deliberation: Two intertwined figures appear: (1) "the fracture/wound of the daughter of my people" and attempts to heal it lightly is an extended medical metaphor for the nation’s deep spiritual and social crisis; (2) "daughter of my people" itself is a collective personification of the nation as a vulnerable female.

instances.english_text: They offer healing offhand for the fracture of the daughter of my people
target: Judah’s deep spiritual, social, and political crisis
vehicle: a daughter with a serious fracture/wound being superficially treated
ground: the people’s condition is gravely damaged yet leaders treat it as minor
mismatch between appearance and reality of healing
exploitation of a vulnerable community
instances.explanation: The nation is personified as a daughter with a serious fracture, and the leaders’ policies and prophecies are pictured as trivial bandaging of a grave wound.

instances.english_text: the daughter of my people
vehicle: a daughter related to the speaker
ground: closeness, affection, and vulnerability of the people before God/prophet
familial bond and protectiveness
emotional stake in their suffering
posture: empathetic lament as well as accusation
instances.explanation: The community is personified as a daughter, expressing both their vulnerability and the speaker’s deep familial concern.

deliberation: The verse uses "fall" and "stumble" in a judgment context, which is a standard metaphor for ruin and defeat. "Time of their visitation" is an idiom for the moment when God intervenes in judgment, not a literal friendly visit.

instances.english_text: Assuredly, they shall fall among the falling; they shall stumble at the time of their doom
target: the fate of the shameless sinners in Judah
vehicle: loss of physical balance leading to collapse
ground: irremediable collapse and inability to stand
sudden downfall with no recovery
vulnerability under external forces
instances.explanation: Falling and stumbling are used metaphorically for catastrophic defeat under judgment, not merely tripping in a literal sense.

instances.english_text: at the time of their doom (literally: at the time of their visitation)
target: the moment when God executes judgment on them
vehicle: "visitation" as though God were coming in person to inspect
ground: God’s personal intervention to reckon with their sins
closeness and intentionality in judgment
divine oversight becoming active punishment
posture: solemn framing of coming crisis as God’s appointed time
instances.explanation: Here "visitation" is an idiom and metonymy for the concrete execution of judgment, not a casual visit, expressing God’s deliberate intervention.

deliberation: The image of vine and fig tree without fruit and withered leaves may refer to literal agricultural devastation, but in prophetic tradition vine and fig tree are standard metaphors for Israel’s fruitfulness. The clustered imagery functions as a metaphor for complete loss of covenant blessings and productivity.

instances.hebrew_text: אֵין עֲנָבִים בַּגֶּפֶן וְאֵין תְּאֵנִים בַּתְּאֵנָה וְהֶעָלֶה נָבֵל
instances.english_text: No grapes left on the vine, no figs on the fig tree, the leaves all withered
vehicle: a barren vine and fig tree with withered leaves
ground: absence of expected results and blessings
visible sign of curse and decay
failure to produce the fruit appropriate to their calling
posture: announcement of covenant curse using agrarian symbolism
instances.explanation: The unfruitful vine and fig tree with withered leaves portray the people’s loss of blessing and failure to yield the righteous fruit God sought.

deliberation: The key figurative phrase is "he has made us drink water of gall/poison"; this is a standard prophetic metaphor for bitter, deadly experiences of judgment, not literal medicinal drinking.

instances.english_text: And he has made us drink a bitter draft (water of gall), because we sinned against GOD
target: the people’s experience of divine judgment
ground: their punishment is deeply bitter and harmful, forced upon them
inescapable, internalized consequences of sin
God as one who administers a cup of judgment
instances.explanation: The people’s suffering under judgment is portrayed as being forced to drink an intensely bitter or poisonous drink, emphasizing the unpleasantness and compulsion.

deliberation: The verse contrasts hoped-for peace and healing with terror. The phrase "time of healing" is a continuation of the medical metaphor in this chapter, picturing national restoration as convalescence; its frustration is the point.

instances.english_text: For a time of healing—but instead, there is terror!
vehicle: a scheduled time of medical healing
ground: they expected improvement and relief but encountered the opposite
misalignment between expectation and reality
diagnosed condition worsens instead of heals
instances.explanation: Restoration is envisioned as a time of healing, but terror arrives instead, continuing the medical metaphor for the nation’s condition and its failed recovery.

deliberation: Two figurative elements stand out: (1) the land "quaking" at the sound of the invaders’ horses—a vivid, likely hyperbolic personification of the land reacting in fear; (2) the invaders "devour" the land, its fullness, the city and inhabitants—an eating metaphor for conquest and destruction.

instances.english_text: At the loud neighing of their steeds the whole land quaked.
target: the territory of Judah and its inhabitants
vehicle: earth/land trembling like a living being
ground: extreme disturbance and fear caused by the approaching army
instability and upheaval
overwhelming impact of invasion
posture: dramatic portrayal of the invasion’s effect
instances.explanation: The land is personified as quaking at the sound of the invaders’ horses; this hyperbolic image underscores how profoundly the invasion will shake the country.

instances.hebrew_text: וַיָּבֹאוּ וַיֹּאכְלוּ אֶרֶץ וּמְלוֹאָהּ עִיר וְיֹשְׁבֵי בָהּ
instances.english_text: They came and devoured the land and what was in it, the town and those who dwelt in it.
target: the invading army’s acts of conquest and plunder
impact of enemy forces on Judah
vehicle: devouring the land, its fullness, the city, and inhabitants
ground: total consumption and destruction of resources and people
insatiable and violent appropriation
leaving nothing intact or untouched
instances.explanation: Conquest and plunder are depicted as devouring the land and its residents like food, highlighting the thoroughness and violence of the invasion.

deliberation: The promised "serpents, adders that cannot be charmed" function as a vivid metaphor for dangerous, uncontrollable agents of judgment (most naturally the invading enemies), biting the people. The snake image works figuratively even if there is also a literal threat.

instances.hebrew_text: מְשַׁלֵּחַ בָּכֶם נְחָשִׁים צִפְעֹנִים אֲשֶׁר אֵין־לָהֶם לָחַשׁ וְנִשְּׁכוּ אֶתְכֶם
instances.english_text: I will send serpents against you, adders that cannot be charmed, and they shall bite you
target: the hostile forces or afflictions sent in judgment
vehicle: venomous serpents and adders that cannot be charmed
ground: sudden, painful, potentially lethal harm that cannot be averted
uncontrollability and fear
inescapable injury from small but deadly agents
instances.explanation: Enemies or afflictions sent by God are depicted as venomous snakes that cannot be charmed away, emphasizing the painful and inevitable nature of the coming judgment.

deliberation: The main figurative element is the depiction of the heart as "sick" within the speaker—emotional anguish rendered as physical illness, with the heart used metonymically for the inner self.

instances.english_text: My heart is sick within me
target: prophetic/ divine sorrow over the people
ground: deep, debilitating inner distress analogous to physical sickness
weakness, pain, and heaviness
disrupted well-being
instances.explanation: The speaker’s profound grief is portrayed as a sick heart, using bodily illness as a metaphor and "heart" as a metonym for the inner person.

deliberation: Two figurative elements recur: (1) "the daughter of my people" as a personification of the nation; (2) "alien vanities" (literally breaths/vapors) as a metaphor for the idols’ emptiness and worthlessness.

instances.english_text: Hark! The outcry of the daughter of my people from a distant land
target: the exiled or suffering people of Judah
vehicle: a daughter crying out from far away
ground: vulnerability, dependency, and pain calling for response
familial bond between speaker and people
pathos of exile as a child far from home
instances.explanation: The nation is again personified as a daughter crying out from exile, heightening the emotional impact of their suffering and estrangement.

instances.english_text: with their images, with alien futilities (literally: foreign vanities/breaths)
target: the idols and foreign cult objects they worship
ground: worthlessness, powerlessness, and insubstantiality of idols
transience and emptiness
contrast with the solid reality of YHWH
instances.explanation: Idols are called "vanities" (breaths), metaphorically portraying them as insubstantial nothings, emphasizing their futility.

deliberation: The proverb-like saying mentions harvest and summer as past without salvation. While it may recall literal agricultural cycles, it functions as a temporal metaphor for the passing of all expected windows of deliverance.

instances.hebrew_text: עָבַר קָצִיר כָּלָה קָיִץ וַאֲנַחְנוּ לֹא נוֹשָׁעְנוּ
instances.english_text: Harvest is past, summer is gone, but we have not been saved.
target: the hoped-for occasions of deliverance for the people
vehicle: the agricultural seasons of harvest and summer passing
fixed temporal windows in the year
times associated with plenty and completion
ground: all expected times for help have come and gone without result
finality and irreversibility of missed opportunities
sense of belatedness and despair
instances.explanation: The passing of harvest and summer symbolizes that all anticipated periods of rescue are over, yet salvation has not come.

deliberation: Again the nation is portrayed as "the daughter of my people" with a "shattering/breaking," and the speaker says "I am shattered." This extends the bodily-breakage metaphor: national catastrophe and the speaker’s grief are depicted as physical fracture.

instances.english_text: Because my people is shattered, I am shattered
target: the catastrophic condition of Judah and the speaker’s grief
state of the covenant community and its representative
vehicle: shattering/breaking of a body or object
ground: deep, painful, and possibly irreparable damage
shared suffering between people and prophet
intensity of emotional and communal trauma
posture: empathetic identification with the people’s fate
instances.explanation: The people’s calamity and the prophet’s grief are pictured as physical shattering, with the nation again personified as a daughter, highlighting severity of suffering.

deliberation: The questions about balm in Gilead, a physician, and healing for the daughter of my people create an extended medical metaphor: spiritual/political restoration is framed as medical treatment and recovery for a patient-nation.

instances.hebrew_text: הַצֳּרִי אֵין בְּגִלְעָד אִם־רֹפֵא אֵין שָׁם כִּי מַדּוּעַ לֹא עָלְתָה אֲרֻכַת בַּת־עַמִּי
instances.english_text: Is there no balm in Gilead? Can no physician be found? Why has healing not yet come to my poor people?
target: the restoration and relief of Judah’s broken condition
vehicle: balm, physician, and medical healing for a patient (the daughter of my people)
clinical care of a sick person
ground: the people’s condition is like an illness needing expert treatment
apparent lack of effective remedy despite renowned resources
continuing sickness indicates unresolved sin/judgment
posture: sorrowful questioning of the absence of restoration
instances.explanation: Gilead’s balm and a physician symbolize effective means of healing, applied metaphorically to the nation personified as a daughter who has not yet recovered.

deliberation: The verse uses striking hyperbolic metaphors: wishing the head were water and the eyes a fountain of tears to enable unceasing weeping for the slain of the daughter of my people. The impossibility underscores the intensity of grief.

instances.hebrew_text: מִי־יִתֵּן רֹאשִׁי מַיִם וְעֵינִי מְקוֹר דִּמְעָה וְאֶבְכֶּה יוֹמָם וָלַיְלָה
instances.english_text: Oh, that my head were water, my eyes a fount of tears! Then would I weep day and night
target: the speaker’s capacity for mourning over the slain of the people
vehicle: a head made of water and eyes as a spring/fountain of tears
ground: desire for limitless ability to weep, matching the scale of loss
continuous, abundant expression of sorrow
grief beyond normal human capacity
instances.explanation: By imagining a head of water and eyes as a fountain, the speaker hyperbolically expresses a desire to weep without ceasing for the nation’s dead.
